author: Nathalie Tadena
title: Big Bird’s Caroll Spinney Talks Storytelling in Ads
text:
0 COMMENTS Big Bird has a lesson for brands – use humor and emotion.
Caroll Spinney, who has voiced the “Sesame Street” character since 1969, said much of Big Bird’s enduring success with children is thanks to the character’s ability to express a range of emotions.
“He gets to be almost more human than the humans on the show,” Mr. Spinney said of his iconic 8-foot-2-inch character during a presentation at Advertising Week in New York. “He’s not very bird-like aside from the fact he’s covered in feathers and lives in a nest.”
Mr. Spinney sported a tie with images of his other well-known character Oscar the Grouch during his talk on Monday with DigitasLBI Chief Content Officer Scott Donaton titled “Enduring Stories: A (Big) Bird’s Eye View.” The puppeteer said humor in particular can be very powerful in connecting with viewers, something marketers should take note of. Brands can step up their game in producing ads that grip viewers with emotion, Mr. Spinney said, adding that the best commercials tell a story. “Quite a lot can be said” in a spot that’s only 20 seconds long, Mr. Spinney said.
“Commercials are not always something you want to avoid. Some of them are actually fun,” Mr. Spinney said.
While Big Bird has built a loyal following among generations of viewers, “Sesame Street” – like the broader television industry – has had to adapt to keep up with a changing media landscape.
Starting this fall, new episodes of “Sesame Street” will be broadcast on cable network HBO first before they appear on their long-time home of PBS. The deal allows “Sesame Street” to produce 35 new episodes a year, up from 18, and also beefs up children’s content available for HBO’s online services as young viewers increasingly watch on-demand streaming services.
“It’s a marvelous thing that’s happened,”Mr. Spinney said. “All of this will help us broaden our reach.”
And even as computer-generated animation gains in popularity among children, there’s still an appetite for puppetry, Mr. Spinney said.
“With puppets, they can be instant. They can react to something you just said,” Mr. Spinney said. “That’s the beauty of puppetry.”
